line: Introduction
label: heading

line: Welcome to The Windows Interface Guidelines ⎯ A Guide for Designing Software, an
label: paragraph

line: indispensable guide to designing software that runs with the Microsoft®Windows®
label: paragraph

line: operating system. The design of your software's interface, more than anything else,
label: paragraph

line: affects how a user experiences your product. This guide promotes good interface
label: paragraph

line: design and visual and functional consistency within and across Windows-based
label: paragraph

line: applications.

line: What's New
label: heading

line: Continuing the direction set by Microsoft OLE, the enhancements in the Windows
label: paragraph

line: user interface provide a design evolution from the basic and graphical to the more
label: paragraph

line: object oriented ⎯ that is, from an application-centered interface to a more data-
label: paragraph

line: centered one. In response, developers and designers may need to rethink the interface
label: paragraph

line: of their software ⎯ the basic components and the respective operations and properties
label: paragraph

line: that apply to them. This is important because, from a user's perspective, applications
label: paragraph

line: have become less the primary focus and more the engines behind the objects in the
label: paragraph

line: interface. Users can now interact with data without having to think about applications,
label: paragraph

line: allowing them to better concentrate on their tasks.

line: How to Apply the Guidelines
label: heading

line: This guide promotes visual and functional consistency within and across the Windows
label: paragraph

line: operating system. Although following these guidelines is encouraged, you are free to
label: paragraph

line: adopt the guidelines that best suit your software. However, you and your customers
label: paragraph

line: will benefit if, by following these guidelines, you enable users to transfer their skills
label: paragraph

line: and experience from one task to the next and to learn new tasks easily. The data-
label: paragraph

line: centered design environment begins to break down the lines between traditional
label: paragraph

line: application domains. Inconsistencies in the interface become more obvious and more
label: paragraph

line: distracting to users.
label: paragraph

line: Conversely, adhering to the design guidelines does not guarantee usability. The
label: paragraph

line: guidelines are valuable tools, but they must be combined with other factors as part of
label: paragraph

line: an effective software design process, such factors as application of design principles,
label: paragraph

line: task analysis, prototyping, and usability evaluation.
label: paragraph

line: You may extend these guidelines, provided that you do so in the spirit of the principles
label: paragraph

line: on which they are based, and maintain a reasonable level of consistency with the
label: paragraph

line: visual and behavioral aspects of the Windows interface. In general, avoid adding new
label: paragraph

line: elements or behaviors unless the interface does not otherwise support them. More
label: paragraph

line: importantly, avoid changing an existing behavior for common elements. A user builds
label: paragraph

line: up expectations about the workings of an interface. Inconsistencies not only confuse
label: paragraph

line: the user, they also add unnecessary complexity.
label: paragraph

line: These guidelines supersede those issued for Windows version 3.1 and all previous
label: paragraph

line: releases and are specific to the development of applications designed for Microsoft®
label: paragraph

line: Windows® 95, Microsoft® Windows NT™ Workstation 3.51 (and Microsoft®
label: paragraph

line: Windows NT Server 3.51), and later releases. There is no direct relationship between
label: paragraph

line: these guidelines and those provided for other operating systems.

line: Design Principles and Methodology
label: heading

line: A well-designed user interface is built on principles and a development process that centers on users and their tasks.
label: paragraph

line: This chapter summarizes the basic principles of the interface design for Microsoft Windows. It also includes
label: paragraph

line: techniques and methodologies employed in an effective human-computer interface design process.
label: paragraph

line: User-Centered Design Principles
label: heading

line: The information in this section describes the design principles on which Windows and the guidelines in this book are
label: paragraph

line: based. You will find these principles valuable when designing software for Windows.
label: paragraph

line: User in Control
label: heading

line: An important principle of user interface design is that the user should always feel in control of the software, rather
label: paragraph

line: than feeling controlled by the software. This principle has a number of implications.
label: paragraph

line: T he first implication is the operational assumption that actions are started not by the computer or the software but by
label: paragraph

line: the user, a user who plays an active, rather than reactive, role. Task automation and constraints are still possible, but
label: paragraph

line: you should implement them in a balanced way that allows the user freedom of choice.
label: paragraph

line: T he second implication is that users, because of their widely varying skills and preferences, must be able to
label: paragraph

line: customize aspects of the interface. The system software provides user access to many of these aspects. Your software
label: paragraph

line: should reflect user settings for different system properties such as color, fonts, or other options.
label: paragraph

line: T he final implication is that your software should be as interactive and responsive as possible. Avoid modes
label: paragraph

line: whenever possible. A mode is a state that excludes general interaction or otherwise limits the user to specific
label: paragraph

line: interactions. When a mode is the only or the best design alternative⎯for example, for selecting a particular tool in a
label: paragraph

line: drawing program⎯make certain the mode is obvious, visible, the result of an explicit user choice, and easy to
label: paragraph

line: cancel.
label: paragraph

line: For information about applying the design principle of user in control, see Chapter 4, "Input Basics," and Chapter 5,
label: paragraph

line: "General Interaction Techniques." These chapters cover the basic forms of interaction your software should support.
label: paragraph

line: Directness
label: heading

line: Design your software so that users can directly manipulate software representations of information. Whether
label: paragraph

line: dragging an object to relocate it or navigating to a location in a document, users should see how the actions they take
label: paragraph

line: affect the objects on the screen. Visibility of information and choices also reduce the user's mental workload. Users
label: paragraph

line: can recognize a command easier than they can recall its syntax.
label: paragraph

line: Familiar metaphors provide a direct and intuitive interface to user tasks. By allowing users to transfer their
label: paragraph

line: knowledge and experience, metaphors make it easier to predict and learn the behaviors of software-based
label: paragraph

line: representations.
label: paragraph

line: When using metaphors, you need not limit a computer-based implementation to its "real world" counterpart. For
label: paragraph

line: example, unlike its paper-based counterpart, a folder on the Windows desktop can be used to organize a variety of
label: paragraph

line: objects such as printers, calculators, and other folders. Similarly, a Windows folder can be more easily resorted. The
label: paragraph

line: purpose of using metaphor in the interface is to provide a cognitive bridge; the metaphor is not an end in itself.

label: paragraph

line: Metaphors support user recognition rather than recollection. Users remember a meaning associated with a familiar
label: paragraph

line: object easier than they remember the name of a particular command.
label: paragraph

line: For information about applying the principle of directness and metaphor, see Chapter 5, "General Interaction
label: paragraph

line: Techniques," and Chapter 13, "Visual Design." These chapters cover, respectively, the use of directness in the
label: paragraph

line: interface (including drag and drop) and the use of metaphors when designing icons or other graphical elements.
label: paragraph

line: Consistency
label: heading

line: Consistency allows users to transfer existing knowledge to new tasks, learn new things more quickly, and focus more
label: paragraph

line: on tasks because they need not spend time trying to remember the differences in interaction. By providing a sense of
label: paragraph

line: stability, consistency makes the interface familiar and predictable.
label: paragraph

line: Consistency is important through all aspects of the interface, including names of commands, visual presentation of
label: paragraph

line: information, and operational behavior. To design consistency into software, you must consider several aspects.
label: paragraph

line: Consistency within a product. Present common functions using a consistent set of commands and
label: paragraph

line: interfaces. For example, do not provide a Copy command that immediately carries out an operation
label: paragraph

line: in one situation but in another presents a dialog box that requires a user to type in a destination. As
label: paragraph

line: a corollary to this example, use the same command to carry out functions that seem similar to the
label: paragraph

line: user.
label: paragraph

line: Consistency within the operating environment. By maintaining a high level of consistency between
label: paragraph

line: the interaction and interface conventions provided by
label: paragraph

line: Windows, your software benefits from users' ability to apply interaction skills they have already
label: paragraph

line: learned.
label: paragraph

line: Consistency with metaphors. If a particular behavior is more characteristic of a different object
label: paragraph

line: than its metaphor implies, the user may have difficulty learning to associate that behavior with an
label: paragraph

line: object. For example, an incinerator communicates a different model than a wastebasket for the
label: paragraph

line: recoverability of objects placed in it.
label: paragraph

line: Although applying the principle of consistency is the primary goal of this guide, the following chapters focus on the
label: paragraph

line: elements common to all Windows-based software: Chapter 6, "Windows," Chapter 7, "Menus, Controls, and
label: paragraph

line: Toolbars," and Chapter 8, "Secondary Windows." For information about closely integrating your software with the
label: paragraph

line: Windows environment, see Chapter 10, "Integrating with the System," and Chapter 11, "Working with OLE
label: paragraph

line: Embedded and OLE Linked Objects."
label: paragraph

line: Forgiveness
label: heading

line: Users like to explore an interface and often learn by trial and error. An effective interface allows for interactive
label: paragraph

line: discovery. It provides only appropriate sets of choices and warns users about potential situations where they may
label: paragraph

line: damage the system or data, or better, makes actions reversible or recoverable.
label: paragraph

line: Even within the best designed interface, users can make mistakes. These mistakes can be both physical (accidentally
label: paragraph

line: pointing to the wrong command or data) and mental (making a wrong decision about which command or data to
label: paragraph

line: select). An effective design avoids situations that are likely to result in errors. It also accommodates potential user
label: paragraph

line: errors and makes it easy for the user to recover.
label: paragraph

line: For information about applying the principle of forgiveness, see Chapter 12, "User Assistance," which provides
label: paragraph

line: information on supporting discoverability in the interface through the use of contextual, task-oriented, and reference

line: Feedback
label: heading

line: Always provide feedback for a user's actions. Visual, and sometimes audio, cues should be presented with every user
label: paragraph

line: interaction to confirm that the software is responding to the user's input and to communicate details that distinguish
label: paragraph

line: the nature of the action.
label: paragraph

line: Effective feedback is timely, and is presented as close to the point of the user's interaction as possible. Even when the
label: paragraph

line: computer is processing a particular task, provide the user with information regarding the state of the process and how
label: paragraph

line: to cancel that process if that is an option. Nothing is more disconcerting than a "dead" screen that is unresponsive to
label: paragraph

line: input. A typical user will tolerate only a few seconds of an unresponsive interface.
label: paragraph

line: It is equally important that the type of feedback you use be appropriate to the task. Pointer changes or a status bar
label: paragraph

line: message can communicate simple information; more complex feedback may require the display of a message box.
label: paragraph

line: For information about applying the principle of visual and audio feedback, see Chapter 13, "Visual Design," and
label: paragraph

line: Chapter 14, "Special Design Considerations."
label: paragraph

line: Aesthetics
label: heading

line: The visual design is an important part of a software's interface. Visual attributes provide valuable impressions as well
label: paragraph

line: as communicate important cues to the interaction behavior of particular objects. At the same time, it is important to
label: paragraph

line: remember that every visual element that appears on the screen potentially competes for the user's attention. Provide a
label: paragraph

line: pleasant environment that clearly contributes to the user's understanding of the information presented. A graphics or
label: paragraph

line: visual designer may be invaluable with this aspect of the design.
label: paragraph

line: For information and guidelines related to the aesthetics of your interface, see Chapter 13, "Visual Design." This
label: paragraph

line: chapter covers everything from individual element design to font use and window layout.
label: paragraph

line: Simplicity
label: heading

line: An interface should be simple (not simplistic), easy to learn, and easy to use. It must also provide access to all
label: paragraph

line: functionality provided by an application. Maximizing functionality and maintaining simplicity work against each
label: paragraph

line: other in the interface. An effective design balances these objectives.
label: paragraph

line: One way to support simplicity is to reduce the presentation of information to the minimum required to communicate
label: paragraph

line: adequately. For example, avoid wordy descriptions for command names or messages. Irrelevant or verbose phrases
label: paragraph

line: clutter your design, making it difficult for users to easily extract essential information. Another way to design a
label: paragraph

line: simple but useful interface is to use natural mappings and semantics. For example, arranging elements together
label: paragraph

line: strengthens their association.
label: paragraph

line: You can also help users manage complexity by using progressive disclosure. Progressive disclosure involves careful
label: paragraph

line: organization of information so that it is shown only at the appropriate time. By "hiding" information presented to the
label: paragraph

line: user, you reduce the amount of information to process. For example, clicking a menu displays its choices; the use of
label: paragraph

line: dialog boxes can reduce the number of menu options.
label: paragraph

line: Progressive disclosure does not imply using unconventional techniques for revealing information, such as requiring a
label: paragraph

line: modifier key as the only way to access basic functions or forcing the user down a longer sequence of hierarchical
label: paragraph

line: interaction. This can make an interface more complex and cumbersome.
